ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: I took this class as an elective for the physics major. I hadn't taken any G&G classes before. That was probably not the best idea, but it's doable. The class is really not a lot of work (6 psets and a take-home final), but some of it took me a really long time because I wasn't familiar with the material. It's not an intro class, but it's doable if you have a physics background. Professor Federov assumes that you have a background, but will review nearly everything (but really, really briefly). As a heads-up: at least two of the homework assignments involved working in Matlab. Which was interesting and useful, but caught me by surprise.

Gives a broad view of climate dynamics. Interesting course and you will learn a lot. It would probably be helpful to have taken differential equations and fluid mechanics and/or geophysical fluid dynamics prior to taking this course.
